Macro Theme : US Liquidity & Monetary Conditions

US Liquidity & Monetary Conditions: synthesising Fed liquidity, money supply and real-rate signals.

As of 2025-12-05

Gemini Summary

Synthesising Fed liquidity, money supply, SOFR positioning and real-rate signals.

Executive Summary

The overall US monetary regime is characterised by an expansionary liquidity impulse, primarily driven by the significant unwind of the Overnight Reverse Repurchase Agreement (ON RRP) facility. This expansive force is occurring despite ongoing contraction in the Federal Reserve's total assets and bank reserves. Money supply (M2), as of its latest observation, indicates a bullish trend, suggesting underlying growth. However, real interest rates are currently situated in a neutral regime, indicating neither restrictive nor accommodative conditions relative to their medium-term trend.

The divergence between the strong liquidity injection from the ON RRP and the continued balance sheet contraction, combined with a neutral real rate stance, presents a complex monetary backdrop. The M2 signal, while bullish, lags the most recent liquidity composite and real rate observations, warranting consideration of its future evolution.

  • Fed liquidity condition: Expansionary
  • M2 regime: Bullish (as of 2025-10-01)
  • Real-rate regime: Neutral (as of 2025-11-01)
  • SOFR positioning tone: Not available
  • Overall monetary tone: Net supportive due to liquidity flows, but with tightening components and a neutral real rate stance.

1. Federal Reserve Liquidity Dynamics

As of 2025-11-30, the Federal Reserve Liquidity Composite indicates an "Expansion" regime, with a composite score of 1.30. This marks the fifth consecutive month of expansion. The primary driver of this expansionary signal is the substantial reduction in ON RRP usage, which contributed a "Bullish" signal with inverted year-over-year and 3-month changes of -96.17% and -90.29% respectively.

Conversely, both Federal Reserve Total Assets and Reserve Balances continue to exert a tightening influence, with "Bearish" signals for 2025-11-30. Total Assets saw a year-over-year decline of -5.11% and a 3-month decline of -0.77%, reflecting ongoing quantitative tightening. Reserve Balances exhibited more pronounced contraction, with year-over-year and 3-month declines of -10.26% and -10.18% respectively. The M2 Money Stock input to the composite was classified as "Neutral" for 2025-11-30, consistent with missing underlying M2 data for that period, as per methodology.

2. Money Supply (M2)

The M2 Money Supply signal, as of its latest available data on 2025-10-01, is classified as "Bullish". This is supported by a year-over-year growth rate of 4.65% and a 3-month momentum of 1.22%. This sustained positive momentum in M2 has maintained a "Bullish" signal since October 2024, following a prior period of "Neutral" and "Bearish" readings.

The "Bullish" M2 signal suggests an underlying supportive impulse to broad money aggregates, which, when considered with the "Expansion" regime of the Federal Reserve Liquidity Composite, indicates a generally supportive trend in overall liquidity and monetary conditions, despite the M2 data lagging the liquidity composite by one month.

3. Real Interest Rates & Policy Expectations

The US 10-year real yield (DFII10), as of 2025-11-01, is in a "Neutral" regime. The current real yield stands at 1.77%, positioned within a narrow band of its 6-month moving average trend of 1.885%. This indicates that real rates are neither significantly above nor below their medium-term trend, suggesting a balanced stance of monetary policy in terms of real borrowing costs.

There is no information provided regarding SOFR (Secured Overnight Financing Rate) futures positioning, thus no assessment can be made on front-end or medium-term policy expectations or speculative vs. hedger positioning from this source. The neutral real rate signal does not overtly confirm or contradict the expansionary liquidity composite, rather it suggests a non-extreme stance in the inflation-adjusted cost of funds.

4. Synthesised Monetary Regime

The current monetary regime can be classified as a "Liquidity-Driven Expansion with Neutral Real Rates". The strong expansionary impulse from the ongoing ON RRP unwind is the dominant factor, injecting significant liquidity into the system. This offsets the persistent draining from Federal Reserve balance sheet contraction and declining bank reserves. The M2 money supply, while lagging, indicates a bullish trend, supporting a generally easing liquidity environment. However, real interest rates remain in a neutral stance relative to their trend, indicating that while liquidity is ample, the inflation-adjusted cost of funds is not yet signaling an overtly accommodative posture.

Pillar Current Regime Interpretation
Fed Liquidity Expansion Significant net liquidity injection, primarily from ON RRP unwind.
M2 Money Supply Bullish (as of 2025-10-01) Positive growth and momentum in broad money supply.
Real Rates Neutral (as of 2025-11-01) Real yields are aligned with their medium-term trend.
SOFR Policy Expectations Not available No data provided for assessment.

5. Forward Risks

Easing / Supportive Risks

  • Persistently positive liquidity impulse (e.g., slower QT, stabilising reserves)
  • Stabilising or falling real yields from restrictive levels
  • Continuation or re-acceleration in M2 growth
  • SOFR positioning shifting towards a more accommodative policy path

Tightening / Reversal Risks

  • Renewed increase in real yields above trend
  • Reversal in ON RRP dynamics or renewed liquidity drain
  • Deceleration or renewed contraction in money growth
  • SOFR positioning moving towards more persistent tightness or reduced cut expectations

6. Investment Interpretation (Informational)

A liquidity-driven expansionary regime, as currently observed, typically implies more supportive funding conditions and potentially reduced liquidity premia across asset classes. This environment can ease market access for borrowers and may reduce the cost of capital. The ongoing unwinding of the ON RRP, in particular, signals a direct injection of liquidity that can flow into the broader financial system.

However, the concurrent tightening from the Federal Reserve's balance sheet reduction and declining bank reserves, alongside a neutral real rate stance, suggests a nuanced environment. Valuation sensitivity in rates, credit, and risk assets may respond to the net liquidity impulse. Assets typically sensitive to abundant liquidity, such as growth equities or higher-beta credit, might find underlying support. Conversely, the neutral real rate environment suggests that while monetary conditions are not overly restrictive from a real yield perspective, they are also not providing significant disinflationary tailwinds that would compel a re-rating of duration-sensitive assets. The M2 signal, when available, supports a broader liquidity picture, which typically correlates with increased market activity and potential for asset price appreciation in a stable context.
